It is going to be a long short story, but that is fine, just as long as it comes out properly Within the Next Three Itâs interesting when youâre at the end of something and someone asks you to tell the story of how you got there. Do you start at the beginning and tell the story as it progressed? Generally that is how you would proceed...but when the beginning doesnât make sense until you know the end, and the end is too vague and complicated without the beginning and the middle. Then, you must start in the middle. Starting in the middle of the tale, with âa day like any other dayâ does nothing any justice. I personally have never experienced a day that has been the same as any other. Itâs like trying to say identical twins are the exact same replicas of each other. If anyone has passed a day that is the same as âthe other dayâ I would love to meet them and tell them what a boring and horrible life they live, for if you have the privilege to be free, then you should take it. However, there is a period in the year that time ceases to exist, and it is when my ailment started. During that season...summer. In the summer, as a teen on vacation, time lacks any type of its natural flow. Everything becomes a blur of which day, what month. Day becomes the time where you sleep so you can go and play at night. And when you play at night, what you do doesnât matter. There are no rules, no boxes that the rest of the world has to live with. Some of us hunt, others drink, and there are many of us who search for substances that only make the mess of their minds worse. In truth, none if these things pertained to me. I was freed like all of the others, cut loose from the chains that bound all of us. We were liberated from the schedule that made us mechanical. But I stayed on the schedule, I just made it so that I lacked the responsibilities I should have had. So I guess, it was no different for me that summer, not until I had the first dream. Every one of us has had what most call a nightmare. It is a distortion of realities in out minds, where everything is twisted and unusual, and nothing makes sense. There are the times when everything youâve learned as right is wrong, and everything youâve known as wrong only gets worse. Or there are the kinds where you are running from something, or where everything changes and everything youâve worked hard on goes to hell. But there is another kind of nightmare. Those are the ones that come true. Good dreams are wonderful things to have come true, but nightmares are irreversible disasters that fate places before us. Weâve all had a day where everything seems to have gone to hell. You forget your work at home and found out later your rabbit decided he would have a wonderful meal out of your project. And the one person youâve ever liked asked out your best friend, who accordingly accepts and treats you like the ground she walks on. At lunch, your favorite shirt got pasta sauce spilled all over it, and your little brother had infested your closet with bees as a present to you. And he only did it because you caught him snuffing crack and you told your parents. Finally at the end of the day, you feel like it should all just be done and you throw your backpack on the ground and rush to your room. Just so you can bawl your eyes out, knowing that you are in the one safe place that will never be taken away from you... Home, but what if that suddenly gets taken away? It doesnât matter, it wonât happen. We all think that, and I donât blame you, I thought that too. Itâs the kind of thing that only happens in someoneâs worst dreams, but then again, they come true all too often. Now I know, now I realize that dreams are the catalysts to everything, every beginning. Reality is just the solidification to everyoneâs eyes, it is the beginning of the end. I looked like I had been in a train wreck. My face was swollen and purple and the bags under my eyes made me look like I had been snuffing something. I started the shower, the hot water was a relief on my skin, and I could feel the knots in my back muscles begin to fade away. It felt like a steam iron rolling out the wrinkles of a shirt that had been discarded on the floor in a heap. The bathroom light kept flickering. I didnât need it so I turned it off, my hand reaching out of the shower like a person reaching for a dead personâs soul in one of those ghost stories. I tried to get up, but I slipped again and hit my head on the garnet counter, the sharp edge cut into my skin and I fell into a sleep. The clock screeched at me, begging me to make its task finished. Growling, I crawled out of the bathroom, my knees scraped against the floor making bloody streaks because I had bled a small puddle, and the soap and water had mingled with it to make a little mess from hell. It read 6:38 meaning I had been unconscious for the good part of an hour. I rolled my eyes into the back of my head running over the mental checklist of the things I needed to do. The mental checklist that never gets done, the one you ignore.
